Situation1: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story: The register beeped as I counted the last stack of bills, my hands trembling slightly. It was the end of my shift, and the drawer was full of high-value transactions—every cent needed to be accounted for. My manager expected nothing less than perfect accuracy, especially tonight, when the store had been unusually busy. As I double-checked the receipts, my phone buzzed in my pocket. A message from Sister Agnes: “The family next door lost everything in the fire. We’re gathering food and clothes now. Can you come?” My heart twisted. As a nun, I was expected to be there, to serve, to comfort, to act without hesitation. But the cash drawer demanded my attention, and any mistake could mean hours of reconciliation or worse, suspicion. I felt the weight of both uniforms—the apron and the habit—pressing down on me, each tugging me in a different direction. My mind raced, torn between the urgent need for compassion and the strict call for precision.
